column3: I SHALL NOT BE SILENCED!\n
Generally looks good (we can finally kill the damn pull testing bot), though is there any way to access to built binaries after the build finishes?\n
@TheBlueMatt The only way to access the binaries would be to upload them to S3 after compilation. \nhttp://docs.travis-ci.com/user/deployment/s3/\n
Sounds good to me, can we make that happen?\n
Hahahaha @BitcoinPullTester somehow I expected a strong NACK from you.\n

@TheBlueMatt there are actually several ways to deploy, see here: http://docs.travis-ci.com/user/deployment/ . I figured we'd probably use the custom one to push to some server space we control, but s3 would be fine by me as well.\n\nI left deployment out of the original PR because I figured it'd be worth discussing on its own. Same with notifications. Like everything else with Travis, we don't ha
@theuni Yea, we do have a server we can stick crap like this on. As for it being in a separate pull, I dont care, but getting binary output was always one of the nicest features of pull-tester.\n
@theuni why is the travis CI build failing here?\n

Note that we'll need to do the same thing for creating secure scp credentials (ssh key and/or password) for uploading build results as well. I figure we can just knock both of those out at once post-merge.\n
Squashed and removed osx references. Will re-add that once the sdk fetching is more foolproof.\n

Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/p4749_425c7a83899f7ccf5343a24319bc19e1e77363da/ for binaries and test log.\nThis test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-te
ACK, though I'd like to see build outputs available before we turn @BitcoinPullTester off\n

@TheBlueMatt agreed, I'm working on that. It proved to be more challenging than anticipated, since Travis assumes that it will publish from commits and/or tags, rather than pull requests (which makes sense in terms of publishing). Will update here when I've got something worked out.\n
Aren't the executables produced by pull tester mostly useless anyway? The windows ones have been crashing for ages, at least, and I'd expect most Linux people insist on building their own.\n

@laanwj Historically, probably. But now that they match gitian's functionality, they could be more helpful. I probably shouldn't argue that too strongly though, since it's turning out to be a bit of a pain :p\n
When pull-tester was being actively maintained/developed they were very helpful, I know on several occasions pulls were submitted just to get windows binaries.\n
All .o files in my local installation together is a multiple of 100M already. Does it help at all if it can't even cache one full build's results?\n

@sipa: These are non-debug, so significantly smaller than typical dev objects. They're also gzip compressed (see 2 lines down). A full linux build that way results in a ~17mb ccache dir. For reference, the exact same build _with_ debug is 105mb. That's probably more inline with what you're seeing?\n\nAlso, as I see it, there's really no use in keeping more than one version of each object around, s
ACK\n
